abstract: A new show at at the Architectural Association School of Architecture in London features 60 contemporary architecture magazines, fanzines and journals from more than 20 countries.
snippet: A new show at at the Architectural Association School of Architecture in London features 60 contemporary architecture magazines, fanzines and journals from more than 20 countries.
lead_paragraph: Print may be dying, but not in the design world. The exhibition "Archizines," at the Architectural Association School of Architecture in London from Nov. 5 through Dec. 14, features 60 contemporary architecture magazines, fanzines and journals from more than 20 countries. The show's curator, Elias Redstone, who writes the London Underground column for T's blog, The Moment, collected the publications on his travels, compiling them first as an online project (archizines.com), with art direction by Folch Studio in Barcelona. But an exhibition of the print versions makes perfect sense: the power of the Internet notwithstanding, it's more fun to turn real pages than digital ones.
